I was proud to support the House in passing a resolution honoring the life of Charlie Kirk and condemning political violence in all its forms.

Charlie was more than a political leader. He was a fighter for his beliefs, a mentor to young conservatives, and someone who never shied away from standing up for America’s values. His voice inspired thousands to get involved, and his legacy will continue to shape the future of our country.

This resolution honors his life and leadership. We can debate, we can disagree, but we cannot allow violence to silence voices or intimidate people into staying quiet. That is not who we are as a nation.

Today, the Transportation & Infrastructure Subcommittee on Highways and Transit held a roundtable to talk about safety on public transit after the horrific murder of Iryna Zarutska. Her killer had been arrested 14 times and was still released back onto the streets. That failure cost an innocent woman her life.

More officers on buses and trains can help, but the real issue is that offenders aren’t being prosecuted and held accountable. When people are arrested over and over yet face no consequences, they go right back to committing crimes until tragedy strikes.

If we want riders to feel safe, then violent offenders must be kept off the streets, not given another chance to harm someone else.

I sat down with fellow Western Caucus members and utility leaders to discuss the growing challenges wildfires create for power providers across the West. These executives know better than anyone how quickly a fire can destroy homes, our rural towns, and power generation or power transmission that drives up costs for ratepayers. Our conversation centered on the need for better forest management: removing hazardous trees, clearing brush, and giving land managers the ability to do their jobs before sparks turn into disasters. If we want reliable power and safer forests, we need practical action to get ahead of wildfire risk.

Today we celebrate Constitution Day. On September 17, 1787, our Founding Fathers signed the document that guarantees our freedoms, protects our rights, and puts the authority in the hands of the people. More than two centuries later, it remains the foundation of our Republic. https://t.co/swciXejJiM

I was happy to speak with the Essential Minerals Association today about the challenges America’s mining industry faces. We’re blessed with the minerals needed to power our economy and strengthen our national security, but Washington’s red tape makes it nearly impossible to get new projects off the ground. It takes almost 30 years on average to open a mine, which leaves us dependent on China and other hostile nations for what we already have under our feet.

It doesn’t have to be this way. America has the resources, we have the workers, and we should be producing these minerals here at home instead of relying on foreign governments for them.

This week, I introduced H.R. 5225, the Protect Innocent Victims of Taxation After Fire Extension Act, to ensure wildfire survivors don’t get hit with taxes on payments that are supposed to help them recover. The bill keeps these protections in place through 2032 and lets victims claim the exemption in the year they get the payment instead of filing amended returns and waiting for the IRS to send refunds.

This legislation builds on the Federal Disaster Tax Relief Act, which made sure survivors of federally declared wildfires weren’t taxed on disaster payments that cover living expenses, lost wages, or injury and emotional distress. My new bill extends those protections through 2032 so families can focus on rebuilding their lives, not fighting with the IRS.

Twenty-four years have passed since September 11, 2001, yet the memory of that day remains just as sharp. We pause to honor the nearly 3,000 innocent lives lost and the extraordinary bravery of those who rushed in to help, from firefighters and police officers to first responders and ordinary Americans who showed remarkable courage.

This anniversary is a reminder of both the cost of freedom and the strength of our nation when united in purpose. As we remember, we also hold our right to freedom high, refusing to let violence or terror, whether foreign or domestic, shake our resolve. May we always honor those we lost and support those who continue to defend our country.

God bless America.
Today's attack on Charlie Kirk is indescribably sickening. This sort of action severely limits public discourse, penalizing all Americans of all persuasions. Please pray for Charlie Kirk.

Today marks five years since the Bear Fire. Recovery has come a long way, and it was good to meet with residents and share updates on recovery efforts. Cal Fire is putting $500,000 toward removing hazardous trees around homes, starting this fall and continuing into the spring. The recovery that’s taken place is a credit to the hard work of those rebuilding, along with support from County, State, and Federal partners.

Today, in the House Natural Resources Subcommittee on Water, Wildlife, and Fisheries, I spoke in favor of my bill, H.R. 4970, the Orland Project Water Management Act. This bill allows water from the Orland Project of the Bureau of Reclamation in Glenn County to be transferred to the Central Valley Project whenever it’s available, not just during drought emergencies.

For years, surface water that could have helped irrigate nearby farms and reduce pressure on groundwater use has gone unused because of outdated federal restrictions. This is water already stored behind a federal dam system, and it should be put to good use. This bill ensures we’re not wasting water in years when it’s available. It’s a sensible fix that supports agriculture and gives water managers another tool to meet local needs.

I was happy to speak at the Paradise Rotary Club luncheon to share an update on what’s happening both in Washington and here in District 1. We talked about local priorities like the sewer project and folks finally receiving their long-overdue IRS refunds. I also covered what’s going on in DC with tariffs, the Farm Bill, Medicaid, immigration, and the push to stop electric vehicle mandates. Always glad to have these conversations and hear what’s on people’s minds here in Paradise.

This month, I hosted town halls in Chico, Red Bluff, Alturas, Susanville, and Yuba City. Some of them were rather spirited. We had important conversations about issues that matter most to our region—the One Big Beautiful Bill, the growing overreach of state and federal government, healthcare concerns, Sacramento’s redistricting plans and what they could mean for rural representation, and the wolf problem impacting ranchers. Thank you to everyone who came out to share your thoughts and ask questions.

Once again, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin is right on the money. California wasn’t elected to run the country, but they sure act like it. This latest move would force every heavy-duty truck, even those from other states and countries, to follow their extreme climate rules.

EPA is right to shut this down. California can’t trample the Constitution or federal law just to push an agenda that raises costs for truckers and every American who depends on them. One state should never control the entire supply chain.

I’ll keep backing efforts to stop these illegal power grabs and stand with the people who keep America moving.

If you want to know what’s wrong with these maps – just take a look at them.  How on earth does Modoc County on the Nevada and Oregon Border have any common interest with Marin County and the Golden Gate Bridge?    Voters took this power from Sacramento for just this reason. This is naked politics at its worst.  This action by the state will set off a series of retaliation in other states across the country with Florida, Missouri and Indiana looking to push back against California. Mid-Decade redistricting is wrong, no matter where it’s being done.  Defying the voters voice is wrong. We should be listening to Californians who have said in multiple statewide elections that politicians shouldn’t be the ones doing the redistricting.  California is already in a huge budget deficit, we don’t need to spend another $235 million or more to learn voters still hate the idea
This is an absolutely ridiculous gerrymander!  Anyone who knows anything about California should be outraged.

The people of California voted twice to take the power of redistricting away from legislators.  This is a blatant power grab by those who want to draw new lines so they can run for Congress.  It’s corrupt. California’s constitution forbids the state from mid-decade redistricting, and forbids legislators from drawing lines - yet clearly they already have drawn the line and are hiding them.

California’s State Constitution prohibits politicians from drawing their own districts and doing mid-decade redistricting. Yet Democrat Members of Congress, Gavin Newsom, and Democrat Legislators (some who want to be members of Congress) are conspiring behind closed doors to draw new district lines. This is wrong. Politicians shouldn’t be picking their voters. They shouldn’t be violating the clear words of the state constitution.
 
This move is more about Gavin’s 2028 ambitions and trying to be the face of resistance than anything else.  California is likely $20B or more in debt and Democrats now want to spend $250M+ of your tax dollars on a special election just so more democrat politicians can go to DC.

I was glad to attend the opening of Mission Esperanza in Oroville and present a Certificate of Congressional Recognition to mark the occasion. With space to house over 100 people, this new shelter is a major step toward helping those in need find stability, support, and a path forward. The Oroville Rescue Mission has done remarkable work bringing this project to life, and it’s clear that Mission Esperanza will live up to its name by providing real hope to many.

The EPA has proposed repealing the so-called “Endangerment Finding” rule from 2009 that gave unelected bureaucrats a blank check to regulate everything from gas cars and trucks to lawn mowers, gas stoves, and more.

This rule has been used to justify over $1 trillion in regulations and forced electric vehicle mandates that limit choice, disrupt supply chains, and drive up prices for families.

CO₂ is not a pollutant—it’s a basic building block of life. At 0.04% of the atmosphere, it’s nowhere near a threat to the planet. The Earth has had much higher CO₂ levels long before anyone was driving an SUV.

I applaud President Trump and Administrator Zeldin for ending this regulatory overreach and putting the brakes on nonsense mandates. This is a return to real-world thinking and it puts the American people back in the driver’s seat.

It was an honor to celebrate Lyle Phillips’ 100th birthday in Oroville over the weekend. A U.S. Marine who served in some of the most difficult battles of WWII, Mr. Phillips went on to serve his hometown as a volunteer firefighter for over 50 years. Seeing him surrounded by his family, friends, and over 20 retired firemen who came to pay their respects was a powerful reminder of what service and legacy really mean. Happy 100th, Mr. Phillips, and thank you.

American workers across dozens of industries, including cops and firefighters, depend on overtime pay to support their families. No tax on overtime will help those workers keep more of their hard-earned money and boost the economy. Our “One Big Beautiful Bill” Act that was signed into law, lowers taxes!

The voters took redistricting power away from the California Legislature in 2010 for a reason. They created the Citizens Redistricting Commission to keep partisan politics out of the process, because politicians shouldn’t be allowed to rig the maps to protect their own power.

Now Gavin Newsom and Sacramento Democrats want to dismantle the very system Californians put in place to ensure fairness and accountability. That’s not “democracy”. It’s a partisan power grab.

The whole point of the independent commission is to protect voters from exactly this kind of political manipulation. Throwing it out to score short-term political points would set a dangerous precedent and take us down a path where redistricting becomes just another tool to punish your opponents. This move will set off an avalanche of blue-state and red-state redistricting that threatens the fabric of the Republic. It’s shameless—and it should be rejected outright.
Even in one of the most liberal courts in the country, the Constitution still wins. California's radical gun control agenda takes another hit! Great job CRPA in taking up this fight.

@DNIGabbard just declassified the 2017 House Intelligence Committee majority staff report. This is the final nail in the coffin of the so-called Russia collusion narrative—a hoax that dragged on for years, wasting time, taxpayer dollars, and undermining President Trump’s first term. The report lays out in detail how the Intelligence Community pushed this manufactured story from the start. It was never about national security, it was about politics.

Millions of seniors live on fixed incomes. Our “One Big Beautiful Bill” Act adds an additional $6,000 tax deduction for those 65 and older to help ease the tax burden and allow them to keep more of their Social Security. We are lowering taxes for seniors. https://t.co/oYtDlYLGnR
It's time to put the $4 billion in federal funding for California's High-Speed Rail towards useful infrastructure projects that actually help Californians. https://t.co/iwTehVOK2a

California drivers are stuck with crumbling roads while billions sat tied up in a high-speed rail project that’s decades behind schedule and over $100 billion short. Today, I joined my California Republican colleagues in urging the U.S. Department of Transportation to redirect the $4 billion recently recovered from that failure into long-overdue upgrades for our highways.

We outlined projects that matter: repairing and expanding I-5, 395, 99, 65, and 70; improvements near San Luis Reservoir and Lake Shasta to support water storage; and moving forward on the Marysville bypass.

It’s time to stop wasting money on fantasy trains and start fixing the roads people actually use. Let’s clear bottlenecks, move freight faster, and make it easier for Californians to get where they need to go.

Oh look, it's another new lawsuit from Newsom to undermine federal law and prop up his sanctuary state dreams. These federal programs—Head Start, childcare services, food pantries—were created to help low-income American families, not to be handed out to illegal aliens. If we are going to get a handle on our spending and end the magnet for illegal immigration, we must end benefits for non-citizens.

The Trump administration is right to require that federal benefits only go to those who are legally eligible. That’s not controversial. It’s common sense.

California’s push to block this change is solely about continuing to give benefits to those not in our country legally. It’s about clinging to a failed, lawless immigration agenda and forcing taxpayers to foot the bill. I support President Trump’s effort to restore order to our benefits system and ensure that these programs serve the people they were meant to—U.S. Citizens.

The Forest Service is awarding $80 million to support timber innovation. That means real progress for forest health and rural jobs. These funds will help restore mills, grow markets for American wood, and reduce wildfire risk by putting more dead trees to use. I’m glad to see the EPA launching a formal investigation into the toxic pesticides being used at illegal grow sites in Siskiyou County. This isn’t just about illegal marijuana—it’s about banned chemicals contaminating soil and water and organized crime networks operating unchecked in rural California. Thank you to Josh Cook, the EPA regional administrator for taking this seriously for the first time.

Local officials have been raising the alarm for years. With over 170 investigations already conducted by the county, the evidence is clear. I’ll keep pushing for state and federal agencies to follow through and treat this like the serious public safety threat it is. If a regular farmer was using these chemicals the EPA and state would come down on them like a ton of bricks. It’s long past time to hold these illegal grows accountable.

I was pleased to see the House pass the Rescissions Act last night, cutting $9 billion in wasteful federal spending. The bill now heads to President Trump's desk to be signed into law.

This is exactly the kind of action voters sent us here to take. We're cutting junk spending, foreign aid giveaways, woke public broadcasting, and other bloated programs that do nothing for the average American. Washington has a spending problem, and this bill is a strong step toward restoring fiscal sanity and holding federal agencies accountable.

Thank you to the Chico Police Department for their quick work. I am sorry they had to expend time and resources on this nonsense.

This is where we are. That many in the opposition clearly cannot stand the commonsense fact that we are working to root out fraud, cut waste, and stop the abuse of taxpayer dollars. They don’t want to hear that we can help those truly in need without defrauding the people who pay the bills. That our taxpayers are done paying for illegal aliens to get benefits. That we are going to enforce the border.

The caseworkers and staff at my Chico office spend their days helping constituents navigate problems with government agencies. They are helping fire victims get their tax problems solved, Social Security recipients through the maze of paperwork, and Veterans get appointments and care. They help thousands of constituents every year. Stopping them from working is hurting the very people who have run out of options.

This behavior is an embarrassment to those in opposition to what they believe my team and I are about. Sadly, today was just another example of Trump Derangement Syndrome coming home to Chico.

We have schools right here in our district that want to follow the federal interpretation of Title IX, not the radical policies Sacramento is pushing. But Newsom’s agenda leaves them stuck in the middle, risking up to $800 million in federal education funding for California.

Who gets hurt most by this? Rural and northern California schools. While Newsom harms kids with his radical ideology that biological males should be competing in women's sports, our students pay the price.

It was great having @SecDuffy before the T&I Committee today. We dug into some important issues like the Tulelake airport, the boondoggle that is California High-Cost Rail, and these one-size-fits-all EV mandates. I’m glad to see he understands what matters to the North State and is working to make sure our priorities aren’t pushed aside. I look forward to teaming up with him to keep getting results for our region.

Earlier this week, I sat down with Suzanne Alexander and RFD-TV for their Champions of Rural America segment. We discussed budget reconciliation, tax breaks, investing in agriculture, and the outlook for a skinny Farm Bill. 

Watch the interview here: https://t.co/Rq36GaJUn7

Water, forests, and energy security are all covered in this budget reconciliation package. It directs $1 billion to build and upgrade water storage and delivery systems across the West — a big deal for Californians who depend on a reliable water supply.

It also requires the Forest Service and BLM to ramp up timber harvests each year through 2034, putting more wood on the market while improving forest health and returning money to the Treasury.

It even claws back unspent dollars sitting idle in federal agency accounts so that money can actually go to work.

More info on what’s included can be found at the link below: https://t.co/Ka2T1mchfQ

The budget reconciliation package takes a major step toward securing our border. It puts over $46 billion toward expanding and finishing the border wall — with 701 miles of new primary barriers, 900 miles of river barriers, plus upgrades and replacements where needed.

It invests more than $6 billion in new technology to help stop fentanyl and other threats before they reach our streets, and adds hundreds of millions to the CBP fleet so agents can actually patrol the border effectively.

It also hires thousands of new Border Patrol agents and CBP officers to enforce the law and keep this country safe.

More details on what’s included in the border security provisions can be found at the link below: https://t.co/GUz1sChD1n

Medicaid (called Medi-Cal here in California) is supposed to be a safety net for children, people with disabilities, and low-income families. The new budget reconciliation law strengthens that system by making sure it’s focused on those who truly rely on it.

Here’s what’s changing. Able-bodied adults without young kids who choose not to work will now be expected to work, volunteer, or pursue education at least 80 hours a month to keep getting benefits. It’s a commonsense, bipartisan idea that promotes stability and leads to better health outcomes.

At the same time, the law tightens eligibility checks and steps up verification of citizenship and immigration status to help crack down on waste, fraud, and abuse. Over the last decade, improper Medicaid payments have totaled more than half a trillion dollars nationwide, with $56 billion just last year. That’s unacceptable.

For states like California that have pushed Medicaid far beyond its original scope, the law gradually scales back certain federal matching rates, meaning states will pick up a fairer share of the costs. It also closes loopholes that let states draw down extra federal money without actually improving care.

As for concerns about rural healthcare, the law provides $10 billion a year for five years, totaling $50 billion, to help keep small rural hospitals and clinics open. How that money gets distributed in California will come down to the Governor and state officials. It’s critical that Sacramento gets this right so our small towns and rural residents aren’t left behind.

More details on changes to Medicaid can be found at the link below: https://t.co/FTEQhIC8Fu

American energy production gets a strong push forward in the budget reconciliation package. It requires the Interior Department to hold regular lease sales for oil and gas — both onshore across the West and offshore in the Gulf and Alaska — opening up millions of acres that have been tied up for too long.

It lowers royalty rates, extends drilling permits, repeals the methane fee, and streamlines environmental reviews so projects don’t get stuck in endless bureaucratic delays. It also rolls back some of the costly renewable carve-outs from the Biden misnamed “Inflation Reduction Act” while still keeping incentives for other clean energy technologies.

The package directs BLM to open up more coal reserves and makes targeted investments in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and energy infrastructure to keep power reliable and affordable.

More on the energy provisions that were included can be found at the link below: https://t.co/ogLtatBLv4

The budget reconciliation package updates the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by returning to mandatory work requirements and tighter accountability designed to strengthen the program and ensure it serves those who need it most.

Work requirements now cover more adults, including parents with children 14 or older. These changes push for greater participation in work, volunteering, or education programs. Waivers from these rules will be limited to areas with high unemployment, making sure states like California can't exempt the entire state from the work requirement.

Benefit increases going forward will be capped to track inflation, preventing unchecked growth without Congressional approval.

For the first time, states will be responsible for a portion of actual SNAP food benefit costs, not just administrative expenses, encouraging stronger financial stewardship at the state level. The formula for state matching funds will be updated to reflect recent payment error rates, promoting better oversight and reducing waste. When states don't have skin in the game to ensure payment accuracy, the high error rates hurt SNAP recipients the most.

These changes are about making SNAP more accountable, sustainable, and focused on helping Americans get back to work.

More details about changes to SNAP can be found at the link below: https://t.co/W3a5k7W3eN

Meaningful tax relief for working families, seniors, and small businesses is at the forefront of the recently enacted budget reconciliation package. It makes the 2017 tax cuts permanent — avoiding an average $1,700 tax hike — and ensures families keep more of what they earn by doubling the Child Tax Credit and standard deduction.

It cuts taxes on tips and overtime pay, offers new savings tools, expands deductions for seniors, and wipes out the tax on interest for new American-made car loans. It also renews the SALT deduction, provides permanent relief from the death tax for family farms and small businesses, and doubles the expensing limit so local businesses can invest and grow.

There’s support here for farmers through lower borrowing costs, continued Opportunity Zones to draw investment into rural areas, and permanent tax breaks that encourage more production and keep jobs here at home.

More details on tax relief provisions in the package can be found at the link below.

He’s worked diligently to hold the line in Sacramento, keep his Republican caucus strong and on message, and grow our numbers — no small task in this state. Grateful for his steady hand and all he’s done for California. The next GOP leader is going to have very big shoes to fill. Well done, @J_GallagherAD3.
I'm really looking forward to seeing what Harmeet does to Newsom & co for continuing to force boys into girls sports.

This is what a threat to democracy looks like: Congress passes a law, the President signs it, and a judge steps in to block it because she doesn’t like the policy. No real legal basis—just raw politics. She should be impeached.

Today we celebrate the birth of our great nation and the freedoms we hold dear. It’s a reminder of the courage and vision of those who came before us, and the responsibility we all share to keep this country strong.

As we mark 249 years of independence, I hope you enjoy this day with family and friends, and take a moment to reflect on how fortunate we are to live in the United States of America. Have a safe and happy Fourth of July. God bless America!

The House just passed our budget reconciliation package, and it’s now headed to President Trump’s desk.

This package delivers a lot of what we’ve been pushing for years. It means more jobs and a stronger economy, with tax relief that lets working families and seniors keep more of what they earn. It makes Social Security checks tax-free for most seniors, protects Medicare, and makes sure tips and overtime pay aren’t taxed. The median family in our district will save around $3,500 under this bill.

It also invests $1 billion to fix canals and expand water storage, so we can actually hold onto water during wet years instead of watching it wash out to sea. It opens up more of our country for energy and timber production and strengthens crop insurance. There’s also a new $50 billion fund to keep rural hospitals afloat as states change Medicaid formulas, so people don’t lose care close to home.

It puts real resources into securing the border so we can finally finish the wall, hire more Border Patrol and ICE agents, remove criminal illegal aliens, and get this crisis under control. It also gets us back to the principle that if you’re a healthy, able-bodied adult, you should be working.

No bill is ever perfect, but this one moves us a long way in the right direction.

The Supreme Court delivered a major win for our Constitution and for common sense. They put a stop to activist judges using nationwide injunctions to block federal policies, a tactic that’s been used repeatedly to try to derail President Trump’s efforts, including cracking down on illegal immigration, eliminating probationary employees, banning transgender servicemembers or ending DEI programs.

One district judge should never have the power to grind the entire country to a halt. This decision is a big step toward restoring proper checks and balances and making sure the will of the voters isn’t thrown out by a single courtroom.

Huge win today for parents and their right to raise their kids with their own values. The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that parents must be informed of curriculum and have the ability to opt their children out of LGBTQ storybooks and lessons that conflict with their religious beliefs. School boards, teachers and states cannot impose their views on children over our objections.

This is exactly how it should be. Parents, not bureaucrats, decide what’s best for their kids. I’m glad to see the Court stand up for the First Amendment and protect families from being forced into teachings on sexuality and gender that go against their faith.

Starting July 1, California will charge $5 every time you buy ammunition. That’s up from the current $1 fee.

This is outrageous. You don’t have to pay a tax to exercise any of your other constitutionally guaranteed rights—voting, jury trial, speech, religion, cruel and unusual punishment, etc. We shouldn’t have to pay a tax to exercise our Second Amendment rights either.

California’s leaders are once again trying to price law-abiding gun owners out of their rights while doing nothing to stop actual crime.

We need to stop treating the Constitution like a suggestion. This looks like the next, in a long list of California gun laws that need to be struck down. I’ll be sure the Trump Administration's Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice is aware and fighting back.

The Trump Administration is right to hold California accountable for violating Title IX. Letting biological males compete in girls’ sports isn’t equality, it’s erasing the rights of female athletes.

California’s policies have cost young women their records, titles, and fair opportunities. The Department of Education’s findings make it clear that this violates federal law.

The proposed resolution is a step in the right direction. It restores fairness, respects biology, and sends a message that Title IX still means something.

If California refuses to comply, they risk losing federal education funding. That’s their choice, but protecting girls’ sports shouldn’t be up for debate.

I joined every California Republican in Congress in sending a letter to Governor Newsom urging him to stop his latest gas price hikes.

On July 1st, the state gas excise tax will go up again, and CARB’s new regulation is set to add up to 65 cents more per gallon. Californians are already paying $1.44 more than the national average; they don’t need more pain at the pump.

We’re also staring down the shutdown of two major in-state refineries — Phillips 66 and Valero’s Benicia facility — which will cut refining capacity by over 20%. That means less available fuel and even higher prices.

Instead of fixing the supply problem, the Governor is raising taxes and pushing more mandates. A USC study says gas could hit $8.43 a gallon by the end of next year. That’s not just bad policy,  it’s a disaster for everyone.

Read our letter here: https://t.co/BeQu26W1LE

The Forest Service is finally beginning the process to repeal the 2001 Roadless Rule—a policy that’s done more harm than good in the West. As Secretary Rollins made clear, the rule has blocked responsible forest management for over two decades, preventing thinning, logging, and the ability to build roads that are critical for wildfire response and public safety.

This was a Clinton-era regulation pushed through in the final days of that administration, backed by environmental activists with no stake in what actually happens on the ground. The result was more overgrown forests, more catastrophic wildfires, and fewer jobs in rural counties that rely on active forest work to sustain their economies.

Repealing the Roadless Rule won’t fix everything overnight, but it’s a major step toward restoring common-sense forest management and giving local experts the ability to do their jobs.

The President’s decision to carry out a targeted strike on Iranian nuclear sites was the right move. It was necessary, and sent a clear message. No other country has the capability to take out this type of threat. I support President Trump’s decision to take action before it was too late.

Iran’s leaders chant “Death to America” and “Death to Israel” as official policy and they mean it. They’ve made it clear that if they ever got their hands on a nuclear weapon, they’d use it on America and Israel. We could not leave major Iranian nuclear sites operational and intact.  

I hope Iran will take the President’s offer now. They’ve had many chances to give up their weapons ambitions.

California continues to be slapped down in the courts. Great job to FPC for this lawsuit. I fully agree with this statement by the court. “California is Wrong”. 

FPC sued and overturned the unconstitutional 1 gun a month law in California. They won 3-0 at the liberal 9th circuit with two Trump appointees and one Biden appointee.

The Supreme Court got it right. Tennessee’s law protects kids from being pushed into irreversible medical procedures before they’re old enough to understand the consequences. That shouldn’t be controversial. States have a duty to step in when activist agendas try to override common sense.

This is why I have a bill to ban gender experimentation on minors. Vulnerable kids are being deceived into surgeries or life-altering drugs they shouldn’t even have to contemplate. Minors shouldn’t be making permanent decisions to alter their bodies, and adults, especially in the medical field, have no business coercing them into it. Let kids be kids. This isn’t compassionate care, it’s irreversible harm.

These students went through a highly competitive nomination process and stood out for their character, leadership, and dedication to serving our country. I was proud to nominate each of them, and I look forward to seeing the mark they’ll make in our armed forces and beyond.

This year’s appointees are:

Mr. Alexander Willingham – U.S. Air Force Academy
